div.p: STRATO, a philoſopher oſ Lampſacus, diſciple and ſucceſſor in the ſchool of Theophraſtus, about 248 years before the Chriſtian era. He applied himself with uncommon induſtry to the ſtudy of nature ; and aſter the moſt mature inveſtigations, he ſupported that nature was inanimate, and that there was no god but nature. (See Plastic Nature). He was appointed preceptor to Ptolemy Philadelphus, who not only revered his abilities and learning, but alſo rewarded his labours with unbounded liberality. He wrote different treatiſes, all now lost.
